references.A08LAR01USGP: Larrucea, E.S. and P.F. Brussard. 2008. Habitat seleciton and current distribution of the pygmy rabbit in Nevada and California, USA. Journal of Mammalogy 89: 691-699.

references.A80GRE01USGP: Green, J.S. and J.T. Flinders. 1980. Brachylus idahoensis. Mammalian Species 125: 1-4.
references.R12USF01USGP: U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service. 2012. Recovery Plan for the Columbia Basin Distinct Population Segment of the Pygmy Rabbit (Brachylagus idahoensis). Portland, Oregon. 109 pp.
references.N80GRE01USGP: Green, J.S., and J.T. Flinders. 1980. Brachylagus idahoensis. Mammalian Species, 125:1-4.
references.A97KAT01USGP: Katzner, T.E. and K.L. Parker. 1997. Vegetative characteristics and size of home ranges used by pygmy rabbits (Brachylus idahoensis) during winter. Journal of Mammalogy 78: 1063-1072.

habitat_description: Brachylagus idahoensis is associated almost exclusively with sagebrush-steppe (Green and Flinders, 1980a; Katzner and Parker, 1997; Heady et al., 2001; US Fish and Wildlife Service, 2007; Larrucea and Brussard, 2008), but is not limited by any particular species of sagebrush (Weiss and Verts, 1984). Other shrubs found within pygmy rabbit habitat include greasewood (Green and Flinders, 1980a), antelope bitterbrush (Green and Flinders, 1980b), and rabbitbrush (Heady et al., 2001). Specifically, the species is found in areas with greater cover of sagebrush (Weiss and Verts, 1984). For example, Green and Flinders (1980b) observed a mean shrub cover of 46% in sites occupied by pygmy rabbit, versus a mean of 29% for sites from which they were absent. Similarly, Katzner and Parker (1997) observed a mean shrub cover of 43% at occupied sites and 17% at unoccupied sites. Hagar and Lienkaemper (2007) defined shrub cover >40% as suitable for the species, with shrub cover >20% and <40% providing marginal habitat. Likewise, shrub height is another indicator of habitat suitability (Weiss and Verts, 1984), with observed mean shrub heights at occupied sites ranging from 52 cm (Katzner and Parker, 1997) to 86 cm (Hagar and Lienkaemper, 2007), versus unoccupied sites with mean shrubs heights ranging from 25 cm (Green and Flinders, 1980b) to 58 cm (Hagar and Lienkaemper, 2007). Note that though Weiss and Verts (1984) report significantly different values for the species’ shrub cover preferences, their cover calculation methodology was different from those used in other studies. The species avoids recently burned sites, where 13-27 years of growth is required for sufficient vegetative structure to be restored (Woods et al., 2013). Finally, due to the pygmy rabbits’ tendency to burrow as a juvenile (Green and Flinders, 1980a), soil type/depth is another factor that limits its distribution; the species’ has an affinity for deep, sandy loams (Weiss and Verts, 1984; Heady et al., 2001; Hagar and Lienkaemper, 2007; Larrucea and Brussard, 2008).
